article.title: Main Window
article.para: The window's title shows the name of the currently loaded file in square brackets, with an asterisk on it's right side if the file has been changed. If a file is loaded, you will find something like this in the window's client area:

On the far left are the offsets of the first byte in the line in hexadecimal notation. You can choose the offset length or make it automatically adjusted to the length of the largest offset with the OptionsView Settings command or right-click the offsets to increment their lengths or left-click them to decrement their lengths (when auto-adjust is off). Then come the actual byte values, with vertical separating lines after every fourth byte in the line. You can choose the number of bytes to display per line with OptionsView Settings, and also, if it should be automatically adjusted to the window width. To the far right are the character representations of these values, with dotted lines on the left and right of this section. You can choose the character set for these representations as well as the font size with the OptionsCharacter set command. As you can see, the first byte of the second line of the sample hexdump has the hexadecimal value 64 and the corresponding character is a lower case "d". The position after the last byte of the file is marked with a double underscore "__" in the byte section.

Blinking in the window somewhere is a rectangular caret, if the window is enabled. If it is in the byte section, then it stands on either of the two nibbles (half-bytes). If it is in the character section, then it stands on one character corresponding with one byte. In either case the corresponding other representation is shown inverted in the other section.

On the bottom of the window is the status bar, which displays additional information. In the first section of the status bar you can find the current offset of the byte which the caret is marking in hexadecimal and decimal notation. After that come the bits of the current byte. Also in this section, on the right side, is something like this:

These are the values of the byte (B:), the word (W:) and the longword (L:) value starting at this offset in decimal notation. These are computed depending on the setting for signed or unsigned values (Choose with the OptionsView Settings command) and on the binary mode setting, either Little-endian (Intel format) or Big-endian (Motorola format). Choose with the OptionsBinary mode command.
In the second section of the status bar are indicators for:

listitem.simpara: entering mode: "OVR" for overwriting or "INS" for inserting on keyboard input. If Frhed is in read-only mode, then there will be a "READ" here.
binary mode: "L" for Little-endian or "B" for Big-endian.

article.para: In the third section the file size in bytes is displayed.
The status bar can also be used to toggle various parameters and act as a shortcut to certain commands.

The status bar takes into account the same factors when considering if the selected command should be carried out as the menus do when disabling commands. If there are 2 alternatives in one place and one is disabled then the other one will be used.
A single left click in the third section is a shortcut to EditAppend (right is EditFile properties) - Note that this may change in the future.
Clicking in the middle section will toggle the parameter clicked on - ANSI ↔ OEM, READ → INS → OVR → READ… (right-click goes back other way) , L ↔ B.
Left or right clicking in the first section can result in many different things depending on where you click and state of the file opened.

When part of the file is selected you may deselect (cursor goes to the first nibble of the first byte of the selection or last of last for a right click) by clicking in the space on the right or the word "Selected:" or alter the selection using EditSelect block by clicking in the offsets region.
If the file is empty clicking the first part will bring up EditAppend.
If the file is not empty and the cursor is on the end byte then EditGoto will be activated on a left click or the cursor goes to the previous byte on a right click.

article.para: If you have suggestions as to what else the status bar could/should (not) do just drop me (Pabs) a line.
The window also has a vertical and a horizontal scrollbar, which can be used to scroll the view. They don't change the caret position.
